title: Stephen Mangan
text:
Stephen James Mangan (born 16 May 1968) is an English actor, comedian, presenter and writer. He has played <a href="Guy%20Secretan">Guy Secretan</a> in "<a href="Green%20Wing">Green Wing</a>", Dan Moody in "<a href="I%27m%20Alan%20Partridge">I'm Alan Partridge</a>", Seán Lincoln in "<a href="Episodes%20%28TV%20series%29">Episodes</a>", Bigwig in "<a href="Watership%20Down%20%28TV%20series%29">Watership Down</a>", Postman Pat in "", Richard Pitt in "<a href="Hang%20Ups%20%28TV%20series%29">Hang Ups</a>" and Andrew in "<a href="Bliss%20%282018%20TV%20series%29">Bliss</a>" (2018).
As a stage actor, he was <a href="63rd%20Tony%20Awards">Tony-nominated</a> for his portrayal of Norman in "<a href="The%20Norman%20Conquests">The Norman Conquests</a>" on Broadway. He also starred as <a href="Bertie%20Wooster">Bertie Wooster</a> in "<a href="Jeeves%20and%20Wooster%20in%20Perfect%20Nonsense">Jeeves and Wooster in Perfect Nonsense</a>" at the <a href="Duke%20of%20York%27s%20Theatre">Duke of York's Theatre</a> in the <a href="West%20End%20theatre">West End</a>, which won the <a href="2014%20Laurence%20Olivier%20Awards">2014 Olivier Award</a> for Best New Comedy. He also presented Children In Need 2020 for the BBC.
Early life and education.
Mangan was born in <a href="Ponders%20End">Ponders End</a>, in <a href="London%20Borough%20of%20Enfield">Enfield</a>, north London, to Irish parents. He has two sisters, Anita and Lisa.
Mangan was educated at two <a href="Independent%20school%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">independent schools</a>, <a href="Lochinver%20House%20School">Lochinver House School</a> for boys in Potters Bar, and <a href="Haileybury%20and%20Imperial%20Service%20College">Haileybury and Imperial Service College</a> (now co-educational), a boarding school in the village of <a href="Hertford%20Heath">Hertford Heath</a> (in Hertfordshire). He was in a school <a href="Progressive%20rock">prog rock</a> band called Aragon, who recorded an album called "The Wizard's Dream."
After earning a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Arts">Bachelor of Arts</a> in <a href="law">law</a> at <a href="Gonville%20and%20Caius%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge</a>, Mangan took a year out to care for his mother, Mary, who died of <a href="Colorectal%20cancer">colon cancer</a> at age 45. Weeks after her death, he auditioned for the <a href="Royal%20Academy%20of%20Dramatic%20Art">Royal Academy of Dramatic Art</a> and went on to study there for three years. His father, James, died of a <a href="brain%20tumour">brain tumour</a> at age 63. Mangan backed the 2020 National Brain Appeal's a charity supporting research at the National Brain Hospital, with a unique online art gallery exhibition sale.
Career.
Theatre.
After graduating from RADA in 1994, Mangan did not pursue lead roles on-screen, preferring to take what he saw as the less limited opportunities on the stage. Between 1994 and 2000, he performed in plays throughout the UK and the <a href="West%20End%20of%20London">West End</a> before joining the theatre company <a href="Cheek%20by%20Jowl">Cheek by Jowl</a> for an international tour of "<a href="Much%20Ado%20About%20Nothing">Much Ado About Nothing</a>", earning him a nomination for a <a href="Royal%20National%20Theatre">National Theatre</a> <a href="Ian%20Charleson%20Awards">Ian Charleson Award</a>. He worked again for director <a href="Declan%20Donnellan">Declan Donnellan</a> at the <a href="Royal%20Shakespeare%20Company">Royal Shakespeare Company</a> in "<a href="School%20for%20Scandal">School for Scandal</a>", and at the <a href="Savoy%20Theatre">Savoy Theatre</a> in "<a href="Hay%20Fever%20%28play%29">Hay Fever</a>".
In 2008 he played the title role in "<a href="The%20Norman%20Conquests">The Norman Conquests</a>", directed by <a href="Matthew%20Warchus">Matthew Warchus</a>, at <a href="The%20Old%20Vic">The Old Vic</a> and then at the <a href="Circle%20in%20the%20Square">Circle in the Square</a> on <a href="Broadway%20theatre">Broadway</a>. The production was a huge critical success earning several <a href="Tony%20Award">Tony Award</a> nominations, including one for Mangan himself and won the <a href="Tony%20Award">Tony Award</a> for Best Revival.
In 2012 he appeared at the <a href="Royal%20Court%20Theatre">Royal Court</a> in a <a href="Joe%20Penhall">Joe Penhall</a> play, "Birthday", directed by <a href="Roger%20Michell">Roger Michell</a>, playing a pregnant man.
Mangan starred as <a href="Bertie%20Wooster">Bertie Wooster</a> in "<a href="Jeeves%20and%20Wooster%20in%20Perfect%20Nonsense">Jeeves and Wooster in Perfect Nonsense</a>" at the <a href="Duke%20of%20York%27s%20Theatre">Duke of York's Theatre</a> alongside <a href="Matthew%20Macfadyen">Matthew Macfadyen</a> as <a href="Jeeves">Jeeves</a> from October 2013 until they were replaced by <a href="Mark%20Heap">Mark Heap</a> and <a href="Robert%20Webb">Robert Webb</a> in April 2014. The production won the <a href="2014%20Laurence%20Olivier%20Awards">2014 Laurence Olivier Award</a> for Best New Comedy.
Television.
Mangan's breakthrough television performance was as Adrian Mole in the six-part <a href="BBC">BBC</a> TV show series "" in 2001. That same year he appeared in "Sword of Honour" on <a href="Channel%204">Channel 4</a>, alongside <a href="Daniel%20Craig">Daniel Craig</a>.
In 2002, he appeared as Dan Moody in the "<a href="I%27m%20Alan%20Partridge">I'm Alan Partridge</a>" episode "Bravealan". A scene where Alan repeatedly shouts "Dan!" at Dan from a distance in a car park, while Dan seems not to notice him, was named the second best moment from the series by <a href="Metro%20%28British%20newspaper%29">"Metro"</a>, and in 2014 Mangan said that he has "Dan!" shouted at him by passers-by almost every day.
Mangan played <a href="Guy%20Secretan">Guy Secretan</a> in the <a href="BAFTA">BAFTA</a>-winning British sitcom "Green Wing". In <a href="Channel%204">Channel 4's</a> "The World's Greatest Comedy Characters", Guy was voted 34th. He starred as Keith in "Never Better", a British television <a href="situation%20comedy">sitcom</a> on <a href="BBC%20Two">BBC Two</a>. He plays a recovering <a href="Alcoholism">alcoholic</a> Keith Merchant and <a href="Kate%20Ashfield">Kate Ashfield</a> is his long-suffering wife Anita. The series was written by <a href="Fintan%20Ryan">Fintan Ryan</a> for <a href="World%20Productions">World Productions</a>.
In 2009, "Free Agents", a <a href="romantic%20comedy">romantic</a> <a href="black%20comedy">black comedy</a> starred Mangan, <a href="Sharon%20Horgan">Sharon Horgan</a> and <a href="Anthony%20Head">Anthony Head</a>. Originally a pilot for <a href="Channel%204">Channel 4</a> in November 2007, the series began on 13 February 2009. It spawned a short lived <a href="Free%20Agents%20%28U.S.%20TV%20series%29">US remake</a>, which was cancelled after just four episodes aired, although four more were later released on <a href="Hulu">Hulu</a>.
He played the title role in "<a href="Dirk%20Gently%20%28TV%20series%29">Dirk Gently</a>", a <a href="Television%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">British</a> comedy detective drama TV series based on characters from the "Dirk Gently" novels by <a href="Douglas%20Adams">Douglas Adams</a>. The series was created by <a href="Howard%20Overman">Howard Overman</a> and co-starred <a href="Darren%20Boyd">Darren Boyd</a> as his <a href="sidekick">sidekick</a> Richard MacDuff. Recurring actors included <a href="Helen%20Baxendale">Helen Baxendale</a> as MacDuff's girlfriend Susan Harmison, <a href="Jason%20Watkins%20%28actor%29">Jason Watkins</a> as Dirk's nemesis DI Gilks and <a href="Lisa%20Jackson%20%28actress%29">Lisa Jackson</a> as Dirk's receptionist Janice Pearce. Unlike most detective series "Dirk Gently" featured broadly comic touches and even some <a href="science%20fiction%20theme">science fiction theme</a>s such as <a href="time%20travel">time travel</a> and <a href="artificial%20intelligence">artificial intelligence</a>. He has said that he was "bitterly upset" at the BBC's axing of the series after four episodes due to a freeze on the licence fee. The four episodes of Dirk Gently were later released on the <a href="BritBox">BritBox</a> streaming service.
He played the title role in "<a href="The%20Hunt%20for%20Tony%20Blair">The Hunt for Tony Blair</a>", a one-off episode of "<a href="The%20Comic%20Strip">The Comic Strip Presents...</a>", a British <a href="television%20comedy">television comedy</a>, which was first shown on <a href="Channel%204">Channel 4</a> on 14 October 2011. The 60-minute film was written by <a href="Peter%20Richardson%20%28comedian%29">Peter Richardson</a> and <a href="Pete%20Richens">Pete Richens</a> and presented in the style of a 1950s film noir. It stars Mangan as the former British Prime Minister <a href="Tony%20Blair">Tony Blair</a>, who is wanted for murder and on the run as a fugitive. The film received its world premiere at the <a href="Edinburgh%20International%20Television%20Festival">Edinburgh International Television Festival</a> in August 2011. It first aired on <a href="Channel%204">Channel 4</a> on 14 October 2011; it received a mostly positive reaction from reviewers, and was nominated for a <a href="British%20Academy%20of%20Film%20and%20Television%20Arts">BAFTA</a> award (Best Comedy Programme 2012) and the <a href="British%20Comedy%20Awards">British Comedy Awards</a> (Best Comedy Drama 2011).
He appeared in "Episodes", a British/American television comedy series created by <a href="David%20Crane%20%28producer%29">David Crane</a> and <a href="Jeffrey%20Klarik">Jeffrey Klarik</a> and produced by <a href="Hat%20Trick%20Productions">Hat Trick Productions</a>. It premiered on <a href="Showtime%20%28TV%20network%29">Showtime</a> in the United States on 9 January 2011 at 9:30 pm and on <a href="BBC%20Two">BBC Two</a> in the UK on 10 January 2011.
The show is about a British husband-and-wife comedy writing team who travel to <a href="Hollywood">Hollywood</a> to remake their successful British TV series, with disastrous results. On 11 December 2013, it was announced that Showtime had renewed "Episodes" for a fourth season. "Episodes" has received positive reviews by critics, with many singling out Mangan, <a href="Tamsin%20Greig">Tamsin Greig</a>, and <a href="Matt%20LeBlanc">Matt LeBlanc</a>'s performances.
In 2018, Mangan played the lead role in a black comedy TV series "<a href="Bliss%20%282018%20TV%20series%29">Bliss</a>", created by American comedian <a href="David%20Cross">David Cross</a>, which was aired on Sky One and released by the <a href="BritBox">BritBox</a> streaming service. "Bliss" stars Mangan as Andrew, a fraudulent <a href="travel%20writer">travel writer</a>, who is struggling to maintain long-term relationships with two partners, Kim (<a href="Heather%20Graham">Heather Graham</a>) and Denise (<a href="Jo%20Hartley">Jo Hartley</a>), who are not aware of one another.
He co-wrote and starred in "Hang Ups" for Channel 4. The show had an all-star cast, including David Tennant, Catherine Parkinson, Charles Dance and Richard E. Grant. It received rave reviews and was nominated for two major awards.
Also in 2018, Mangan starred in the legal drama <a href="The%20Split%20%28TV%20series%29">"The Split"</a> opposite <a href="Nicola%20Walker">Nicola Walker</a>. He reprised this role in the second series in 2020.
It was announced that Mangan will be hosting alongside <a href="Mel%20Giedroyc">Mel Giedroyc</a>, <a href="Alex%20Scott%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201984%29">Alex Scott</a> and <a href="Chris%20Ramsey%20%28comedian%29">Chris Ramsey</a> for the 2020 Children in Need appeal.
Film.
Mangan's first film part was as Doctor Crane in "<a href="Billy%20Elliot">Billy Elliot</a>". He played French cabaret singer Pierre Dupont in the cult film "Chunky Monkey" alongside <a href="David%20Threlfall">David Threlfall</a> and <a href="Alison%20Steadman">Alison Steadman</a>. He appeared in the <a href="Miramax">Miramax</a> film "<a href="Birthday%20Girl">Birthday Girl</a>", starring <a href="Nicole%20Kidman">Nicole Kidman</a> and <a href="Vincent%20Cassel">Vincent Cassel</a>.
He appeared opposite <a href="Keira%20Knightley">Keira Knightley</a> in the 2002 short New Year's Eve, and played the leading role in "<a href="SuperTex">SuperTex</a>" (2003), a Dutch <a href="film">film</a>, filmed in English and directed by <a href="Jan%20Sch%C3%BCtte">Jan Schütte</a>. He played a comedian in <a href="Festival%20%282005%20film%29">"Festival"</a> is a 2005 British <a href="black%20comedy">black comedy</a> about a number of people at the <a href="Edinburgh%20Festival%20Fringe">Edinburgh Festival Fringe</a> directed by <a href="Annie%20Griffin">Annie Griffin</a>. The general shots of the festival were filmed during the 2004 event. Mangan was nominated for a Scottish <a href="BAFTA">BAFTA</a> for his performance.
<a href="Confetti%20%282006%20film%29">"Confetti"</a>, a 2006 British <a href="mockumentary">mockumentary</a> <a href="romantic%20comedy">romantic comedy</a> film, was released on 5 May 2006. It was conceived and directed by <a href="Debbie%20Isitt">Debbie Isitt</a> and stars many British comedians, including <a href="Jessica%20Stevenson">Jessica Stevenson</a>, <a href="Jimmy%20Carr">Jimmy Carr</a>, <a href="Martin%20Freeman">Martin Freeman</a>, <a href="Mark%20Heap">Mark Heap</a>, <a href="Julia%20Davis">Julia Davis</a>, <a href="Robert%20Webb%20%28actor%29">Robert Webb</a>, and <a href="Olivia%20Colman">Olivia Colman</a>. It follows a bridal magazine competition for the most original wedding, the ultimate prize being a house, and the three couples who are chosen to compete. Mangan plays one of the grooms, a professional tennis player.
He starred in "<a href="Beyond%20the%20Pole">Beyond the Pole</a>", a 2010 British <a href="mockumentary">mockumentary</a> adapted from the cult <a href="BBC">BBC</a> radio series of the same name. It received its UK cinema release in 2010. It was directed and produced by <a href="David%20Williams%20%28film%20writer%29">David L. Williams</a>. The film was shot on floating sea ice off the coast of <a href="Greenland">Greenland</a>, and stars an acclaimed cast of actors and comedians including Mangan, <a href="Rhys%20Thomas%20%28comedian%29">Rhys Thomas</a>, <a href="Mark%20Benton">Mark Benton</a>, <a href="Alexander%20Skarsgard">Alexander Skarsgard</a> and <a href="Helen%20Baxendale">Helen Baxendale</a>. "Variety" magazine described the film as a cross between "<a href="The%20Office">The Office</a>" and "<a href="Touching%20the%20Void%20%28film%29">Touching the Void</a>".
In 2013 Mangan played <a href="Alastair%20Caldwell">Alastair Caldwell</a> in "<a href="Rush%20%282013%20film%29">Rush</a>", a British-German <a href="Biographical%20film">biographical</a> <a href="Sports%20film">sports</a> <a href="Drama%20%28film%20and%20television%29">drama film</a> centered on the <a href="Hunt%E2%80%93Lauda%20rivalry">rivalry</a> between <a href="Auto%20racing">race car</a> drivers <a href="James%20Hunt">James Hunt</a> and <a href="Niki%20Lauda">Niki Lauda</a> during the <a href="1976%20Formula%20One%20season">1976</a> <a href="Formula%20One">Formula One</a> motor-racing season. It was written by <a href="Peter%20Morgan">Peter Morgan</a>, directed by <a href="Ron%20Howard">Ron Howard</a> and stars <a href="Chris%20Hemsworth">Chris Hemsworth</a> as Hunt and <a href="Daniel%20Br%C3%BChl">Daniel Brühl</a> as Lauda. The film premiered in <a href="London">London</a> on 2 September 2013 and was shown at the <a href="2013%20Toronto%20International%20Film%20Festival">2013 Toronto International Film Festival</a> before its UK and US theatrical releases on, respectively, 13 and 20 September 2013.
In 2014, Mangan voiced the title role in "", a British <a href="3D%20film">3D</a> <a href="Computer%20animation">computer-animated</a> comedy film featuring <a href="Postman%20Pat">Postman Pat</a>, star of a long-running BBC children's series. It was originally due to be released on 24 May 2013, but was pushed back to a year later. Pat's singing voice was performed by <a href="Ronan%20Keating">Ronan Keating</a>. Other voice actors in the film included <a href="Jim%20Broadbent">Jim Broadbent</a>, <a href="Rupert%20Grint">Rupert Grint</a>, and <a href="David%20Tennant">David Tennant</a>.
In 2020, it was announced Mangan is to write his first film, an adaptation of the children’s novel "<a href="Harry%20and%20the%20Wrinklies">Harry And The Wrinklies</a>".
Other.
Mangan was host of the <a href="Evening%20Standard%20British%20Film%20Awards">Evening Standard British Film Awards</a> for four years (2009–2013). On 27 April 2014, he returned to host the <a href="British%20Academy%20Television%20Craft%20Awards">British Academy Television Craft Awards</a> in London for a third time. Mangan recorded the role of Cloten in <a href="William%20Shakespeare">Shakespeare</a>'s "<a href="Cymbeline">Cymbeline</a>" for the <a href="Arkangel%20Shakespeare">Arkangel Shakespeare</a> audiobook series, directed by Clive Brill. Mangan has been one of the hosts of "<a href="Artist%20of%20the%20Year">Artist of the Year</a>" since 2018.
Personal life.
Mangan is married to actress <a href="Louise%20Delamere">Louise Delamere</a>. They have three sons: Harry (born October 2007), Frank (born 2010), and Jack (born March 2016)
He is a fan of <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.">Tottenham Hotspur</a> and goes to games with <a href="Tamsin%20Greig">Tamsin Greig</a>'s husband <a href="Richard%20Leaf">Richard Leaf</a>.
In August 2014, Mangan was one of 200 public figures who were signatories to a letter to "<a href="The%20Guardian">The Guardian</a>" expressing their hope that Scotland would vote to remain part of the United Kingdom in September's <a href="2014%20Scottish%20independence%20referendum">referendum on that issue</a>.
